This is the weakness to which reli- gious humanity is most apt. The natural development of all religion3‚ especially Judaism, illustrates this. Apart from the inspiration of immediate spiritual insight, we desire a sign so naturally, so deeply——a something visible between Church and world—that we are willing to maim the Church‚ or wrap her in sacerdotal cerements, if only we can claim her grace in peace behind some fortress wall. But when the sect most eager for converts asked Jesus when the Kingdom would come, he answered that it would never come in such out- ward semblance that men could say, “Here it is‚’' and “Here it is not.''
